rule.name: Black listed name "%s"
rule.description: Used when the name is listed in the black list (unauthorized names).

rule.name: Invalid %s name "%s"
rule.description: Used when the name doesn't match the regular expression associated to its type(constant, variable, class...).

rule.name: Missing %s docstring
rule.description: Used when a module, function, class or method has no docstring. Some specialmethods like __init__ doesn't necessary require a docstring.

rule.name: Empty %s docstring
rule.description: Used when a module, function, class or method has an empty docstring (it wouldbe too easy ;).

rule.name: Missing required attribute "%s"
rule.description: Used when an attribute required for modules is missing.

rule.name: Class method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a class method has a first argument named differently than the valuespecified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"),recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

rule.name: Metaclass method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a metaclass method has a first agument named differently than thevalue specified in valid-classmethod-first-arg option (default to "cls"),recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instance methods.

rule.name: Metaclass class method %s should have %s as first argument
rule.description: Used when a metaclass class method has a first argument named differently thanthe value specified in valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-arg option (defaultto "mcs"), recommended to easily differentiate them from regular instancemethods.

rule.name: Line too long (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a line is longer than a given number of characters.

rule.name: Too many lines in module (%s)
rule.description: Used when a module has too much lines, reducing its readability.

rule.name: Trailing whitespace
rule.description: Used when there is whitespace between the end of a line and the newline.

rule.name: Final newline missing
rule.description: Used when the last line in a file is missing a newline.

rule.name: More than one statement on a single line
rule.description: Used when more than on statement are found on the same line.

rule.name: Unnecessary parens after %r keyword
rule.description: Used when a single item in parentheses follows an if, for, or other keyword.

rule.name: %s space %s %s %s
rule.description: Used when a wrong number of spaces is used around an operator, bracket orblock opener.

rule.name: Old-style class defined.
rule.description: Used when a class is defined that does not inherit from anotherclass and doesnot inherit explicitly from "object".
Used when a syntax error is raised for a module.

rule.name: Unrecognized file option %r
rule.description: Used when an unknown inline option is encountered.

rule.name: Bad option value %r
rule.description: Used when a bad value for an inline option is encountered.

rule.name: __init__ method is a generator
rule.description: Used when the special class method __init__ is turned into a generator by ayield in its body.

rule.name: Explicit return in __init__
rule.description: Used when the special class method __init__ has an explicit return value.

rule.name: %s already defined line %s
rule.description: Used when a function / class / method is redefined.

rule.name: %r not properly in loop
rule.description: Used when break or continue keywords are used outside a loop.

rule.name: Return outside function
rule.description: Used when a "return" statement is found outside a function or method.

rule.name: Yield outside function
rule.description: Used when a "yield" statement is found outside a function or method.

rule.name: Return with argument inside generator
rule.description: Used when a "return" statement with an argument is found outside in agenerator function or method (e.g. with some "yield" statements).

rule.name: Use of the non-existent %s operator
rule.description: Used when you attempt to use the C-style pre-increment orpre-decrementoperator -- and ++, which doesn't exist in Python.

rule.name: Duplicate argument name %s in function definition
rule.description: Duplicate argument names in function definitions are syntax errors.

rule.name: An attribute affected in %s line %s hide this method
rule.description: Used when a class defines a method which is hidden by an instance attributefrom an ancestor class or set by some client code.

rule.name: Access to member %r before its definition line %s
rule.description: Used when an instance member is accessed before it's actually assigned.

rule.name: Method has no argument
rule.description: Used when a method which should have the bound instance as first argument hasno argument defined.

rule.name: Method should have "self" as first argument
rule.description: Used when a method has an attribute different the "self" as first argument.This is considered as an error since this is a so common convention that youshouldn't break it!

rule.name: Interface resolved to %s is not a class
rule.description: Used when a class claims to implement an interface which is not a class.

rule.name: Missing method %r from %s interface
rule.description: Used when a method declared in an interface is missing from a classimplementing this interface

rule.name: __exit__ must accept 3 arguments: type, value, traceback
rule.description: Used when the __exit__ special method, belonging to a context manager, doesnot accept 3 arguments (type, value, traceback).

rule.name: Using variable %r before assignment
rule.description: Used when a local variable is accessed before it's assignment.

rule.name: Undefined variable %r
rule.description: Used when an undefined variable is accessed.

rule.name: Undefined variable name %r in __all__
rule.description: Used when an undefined variable name is referenced in __all__.

rule.name: Invalid object %r in __all__, must contain only strings
rule.description: Used when an invalid (non-string) object occurs in __all__.

rule.name: No name %r in module %r
rule.description: Used when a name cannot be found in a module.

rule.name: Bad except clauses order (%s)
rule.description: Used when except clauses are not in the correct order (from the more specificto the more generic). If you don't fix the order, some exceptions may not becatched by the most specific handler.

rule.name: Raising %s while only classes, instances or string are allowed
rule.description: Used when something which is neither a class, an instance or a string israised (i.e. a `TypeError` will be raised).

rule.name: Raising a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException
rule.description: Used when a new style class which doesn't inherit from BaseException israised.

rule.name: NotImplemented raised - should raise NotImplementedError
rule.description: Used when NotImplemented is raised instead of NotImplementedError

rule.name: Catching an exception which doesn't inherit from BaseException: %s
rule.description: Used when a class which doesn't inherit from BaseException is used as anexception in an except clause.

rule.name: Use of __slots__ on an old style class
rule.description: Used when an old style class uses the __slots__ attribute.

rule.name: Use of super on an old style class
rule.description: Used when an old style class uses the super builtin.

rule.name: Bad first argument %r given to super()
rule.description: Used when another argument than the current class is given as first argumentof the super builtin.

rule.name: %s %r has no %r member
rule.description: Used when a variable is accessed for an unexistent member.

rule.name: %s is not callable
rule.description: Used when an object being called has been inferred to a non callable object

rule.name: %s %r has no %r member (but some types could not be inferred)
rule.description: Used when a variable is accessed for an unexistent member, but astroid was notable to interpret all possible types of this variable.

rule.name: Assigning to function call which doesn't return
rule.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred functiondoesn't return anything.

rule.name: No value passed for parameter %s in function call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes too few arguments.

rule.name: Too many positional arguments for function call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes too many positional arguments.

rule.name: Passing unexpected keyword argument %r in function call
rule.description: Used when a function call passes a keyword argument that doesn't correspond toone of the function's parameter names.

rule.name: Parameter %r passed as both positional and keyword argument
rule.description: Used when a function call would result in assigning multiple values to afunction parameter, one value from a positional argument and one from akeyword argument.

rule.name: Missing mandatory keyword argument %r
rule.description: Used when a function call doesn't pass a mandatory keyword-only argument. Thismessage can't be emitted when using Python < 3.0.

rule.name: Unsupported logging format character %r (%#02x) at index %d
rule.description: Used when an unsupported format character is used in a logging statementformat string.

rule.name: Logging format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
rule.description: Used when a logging statement format string terminates before the end of aconversion specifier.

rule.name: Too many arguments for logging format string
rule.description: Used when a logging format string is given too few arguments.

rule.name: Not enough arguments for logging format string
rule.description: Used when a logging format string is given too many arguments

rule.name: Unsupported format character %r (%#02x) at index %d
rule.description: Used when a unsupported format character is used in a format string.

rule.name: Format string ends in middle of conversion specifier
rule.description: Used when a format string terminates before the end of a conversion specifier.

rule.name: Mixing named and unnamed conversion specifiers in format string
rule.description: Used when a format string contains both named (e.g. '%(foo)d') and unnamed(e.g. '%d') conversion specifiers. This is also used when a named conversionspecifier contains * for the minimum field width and/or precision.

rule.name: Expected mapping for format string, not %s
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used withan argument that is not a mapping.

rule.name: Missing key %r in format string dictionary
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with adictionary that doesn't contain all the keys required by the format string.

rule.name: Too many arguments for format string
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given toofew arguments.

rule.name: Not enough arguments for format string
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses unnamed conversion specifiers is given toomany arguments

rule.name: Suspicious argument in %s.%s call
rule.description: The argument to a str.{l,r,}strip call contains a duplicate character,
Used when an error occurred preventing the analysis of a module (unable tofind it for instance).

rule.name: %s: %s
rule.description: Used when an unexpected error occurred while building the Astroidrepresentation. This is usually accompanied by a traceback. Please report sucherrors !

rule.name: ignored builtin module %s
rule.description: Used to indicate that the user asked to analyze a builtin module which hasbeen skipped.

rule.name: unexpected inferred value %s
rule.description: Used to indicate that some value of an unexpected type has been inferred.

rule.name: error while code parsing: %s
rule.description: Used when an exception occured while building the Astroid representation whichcould be handled by astroid.

rule.name: Unable to check methods signature (%s / %s)
rule.description: Used when PyLint has been unable to check methods signature compatibility foran unexpected reason. Please report this kind if you don't make sense of it.

rule.name: failed to resolve interfaces implemented by %s (%s)
rule.description: Used when a PyLint as failed to find interfaces implemented by a class

rule.name: Unable to import %s
rule.description: Used when pylint has been unable to import a module.

rule.name: Unable to run raw checkers on built-in module %s
rule.description: Used to inform that a built-in module has not been checked using the rawcheckers.

rule.name: Unable to consider inline option %r
rule.description: Used when an inline option is either badly formatted or can't be used insidemodules.

rule.name: Locally disabling %s
rule.description: Used when an inline option disables a message or a messages category.

rule.name: Locally enabling %s
rule.description: Used when an inline option enables a message or a messages category.

rule.name: Ignoring entire file
rule.description: Used to inform that the file will not be checked

rule.name: Used deprecated directive "pylint:disable-all" or "pylint:disable=all"
rule.description: You should preferably use "pylint:skip-file" as this directive has a lessconfusing name. Do this only if you are sure that all people running Pylint onyour code have version >= 0.26

rule.name: Suppressed %s (from line %d)
rule.description: A message was triggered on a line, but suppressed explicitly by a disable=comment in the file. This message is not generated for messages that areignored due to configuration settings.

rule.name: Useless suppression of %s
rule.description: Reported when a message is explicitly disabled for a line or a block of code,but never triggered.

rule.name: Deprecated pragma "pylint:disable-msg" or "pylint:enable-msg"
rule.description: You should preferably use "pylint:disable" or "pylint:enable" instead of thedeprecated suppression pragma style "pylint:disable-msg" or"pylint:enable-msg"

rule.name: Method could be a function
rule.description: Used when a method doesn't use its bound instance, and so could be written asa function.

rule.name: Cyclic import (%s)
rule.description: Used when a cyclic import between two or more modules is detected.

rule.name: Similar lines in %s files
rule.description: Indicates that a set of similar lines has been detected among multiple file.This usually means that the code should be refactored to avoid thisduplication.

rule.name: Too many ancestors (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many parent classes, try to reduce this to get asimpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too many instance attributes (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many instance attributes, try to reduce this to get asimpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too few public methods (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too few public methods, so be sure it's really worth it.

rule.name: Too many public methods (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when class has too many public methods, try to reduce this to get asimpler (and so easier to use) class.

rule.name: Too many return statements (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many return statement, making it hardto follow.

rule.name: Too many branches (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many branches, making it hard tofollow.

rule.name: Too many arguments (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method takes too many arguments.

rule.name: Too many local variables (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many local variables.

rule.name: Too many statements (%s/%s)
rule.description: Used when a function or method has too many statements. You should then splitit in smaller functions / methods.

rule.name: Abstract class not referenced
rule.description: Used when an abstract class is not used as ancestor anywhere.

rule.name: Abstract class is only referenced %s times
rule.description: Used when an abstract class is used less than X times as ancestor.

rule.name: Interface not implemented
rule.description: Used when an interface class is not implemented anywhere.

rule.name: Unreachable code
rule.description: Used when there is some code behind a "return" or "raise" statement, whichwill never be accessed.

rule.name: Dangerous default value %s as argument
rule.description: Used when a mutable value as list or dictionary is detected in a default valuefor an argument.

rule.name: Statement seems to have no effect
rule.description: Used when a statement doesn't have (or at least seems to) any effect.

rule.name: String statement has no effect
rule.description: Used when a string is used as a statement (which of course has no effect).This is a particular case of W0104 with its own message so you can easilydisable it if you're using those strings as documentation, instead ofcomments.

rule.name: Expression "%s" is assigned to nothing
rule.description: Used when an expression that is not a function call is assigned to nothing.Probably something else was intended.

rule.name: Unnecessary pass statement
rule.description: Used when a "pass" statement that can be avoided is encountered.

rule.name: Lambda may not be necessary
rule.description: Used when the body of a lambda expression is a function call on the sameargument list as the lambda itself; such lambda expressions are in all but afew cases replaceable with the function being called in the body of thelambda.

rule.name: Duplicate key %r in dictionary
rule.description: Used when a dictionary expression binds the same key multiple times.

rule.name: Else clause on loop without a break statement
rule.description: Loops should only have an else clause if they can exit early with a breakstatement, otherwise the statements under else should be on the same scope asthe loop itself.

rule.name: Use of exec
rule.description: Used when you use the "exec" statement (function for Python 3), to discourageits usage. That doesn't mean you can not use it !

rule.name: Used builtin function %r
rule.description: Used when a black listed builtin function is used (see the bad-functionoption). Usual black listed functions are the ones like map, or filter , wherePython offers now some cleaner alternative like list comprehension.

rule.name: Used * or ** magic
rule.description: Used when a function or method is called using `*args` or `**kwargs` todispatch arguments. This doesn't improve readability and should be used withcare.

rule.name: %s statement in finally block may swallow exception
rule.description: Used when a break or a return statement is found inside the finally clause ofa try...finally block: the exceptions raised in the try clause will besilently swallowed instead of being re-raised.

rule.name: Assert called on a 2-uple. Did you mean 'assert x,y'?
rule.description: A call of assert on a tuple will always evaluate to true if the tuple is notempty, and will always evaluate to false if it is.

rule.name: Attribute %r defined outside __init__
rule.description: Used when an instance attribute is defined outside the __init__ method.

rule.name: Static method with %r as first argument
rule.description: Used when a static method has "self" or a value specified invalid-classmethod-first-arg option or valid-metaclass-classmethod-first-argoption as first argument.

rule.name: Access to a protected member %s of a client class
rule.description: Used when a protected member (i.e. class member with a name beginning with anunderscore) is access outside the class or a descendant of the class whereit's defined.

rule.name: Arguments number differs from %s method
rule.description: Used when a method has a different number of arguments than in the implementedinterface or in an overridden method.

rule.name: Signature differs from %s method
rule.description: Used when a method signature is different than in the implemented interface orin an overridden method.

rule.name: Method %r is abstract in class %r but is not overridden
rule.description: Used when an abstract method (i.e. raise NotImplementedError) is notoverridden in concrete class.

rule.name: __init__ method from base class %r is not called
rule.description: Used when an ancestor class method has an __init__ method which is not calledby a derived class.

rule.name: Class has no __init__ method
rule.description: Used when a class has no __init__ method, neither its parent classes.

rule.name: __init__ method from a non direct base class %r is called
rule.description: Used when an __init__ method is called on a class which is not in the directancestors for the analysed class.

rule.name: __iter__ returns non-iterator
rule.description: Used when an __iter__ method returns something which is not an iterable (i.e.has no `__next__` method)

rule.name: Unnecessary semicolon
rule.description: Used when a statement is ended by a semi-colon (";"), which isn't necessary(that's python, not C ;).

rule.name: Bad indentation. Found %s %s, expected %s
rule.description: Used when an unexpected number of indentation's tabulations or spaces has beenfound.

rule.name: Found indentation with %ss instead of %ss
rule.description: Used when there are some mixed tabs and spaces in a module.

rule.name: Wildcard import %s
rule.description: Used when `from module import *` is detected.

rule.name: Uses of a deprecated module %r
rule.description: Used a module marked as deprecated is imported.

rule.name: Relative import %r, should be %r
rule.description: Used when an import relative to the package directory is detected.

rule.name: Reimport %r (imported line %s)
rule.description: Used when a module is reimported multiple times.

rule.name: Module import itself
rule.description: Used when a module is importing itself.

rule.name: __future__ import is not the first non docstring statement
rule.description: Python 2.5 and greater require __future__ import to be the first non docstringstatement in the module.
Used when a warning note as FIXME or XXX is detected.

rule.name: Global variable %r undefined at the module level
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but thevariable is not defined in the module scope.

rule.name: Using global for %r but no assignment is done
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined through the "global" statement but noassignment to this variable is done.

rule.name: Using the global statement
rule.description: Used when you use the "global" statement to update a global variable. PyLintjust try to discourage this usage. That doesn't mean you can not use it !

rule.name: Using the global statement at the module level
rule.description: Used when you use the "global" statement at the module level since it has noeffect

rule.name: Unused import %s
rule.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used.

rule.name: Unused variable %r
rule.description: Used when a variable is defined but not used.

rule.name: Unused argument %r
rule.description: Used when a function or method argument is not used.

rule.name: Unused import %s from wildcard import
rule.description: Used when an imported module or variable is not used from a 'from X import *'style import.

rule.name: Redefining name %r from outer scope (line %s)
rule.description: Used when a variable's name hide a name defined in the outer scope.

rule.name: Redefining built-in %r
rule.description: Used when a variable or function override a built-in.

rule.name: Redefining name %r from %s in exception handler
rule.description: Used when an exception handler assigns the exception to an existing name

rule.name: Using possibly undefined loop variable %r
rule.description: Used when an loop variable (i.e. defined by a for loop or a list comprehensionor a generator expression) is used outside the loop.

rule.name: Possible unbalanced tuple unpacking with sequence%s: left side has %d label(s), right side has %d value(s)
rule.description: Used when there is an unbalanced tuple unpacking in assignment

rule.name: Attempting to unpack a non-sequence%s
rule.description: Used when something which is not a sequence is used in an unpack assignment

rule.name: Raising a string exception
rule.description: Used when a string exception is raised.

rule.name: No exception type(s) specified
rule.description: Used when an except clause doesn't specify exceptions type to catch.

rule.name: Catching too general exception %s
rule.description: Used when an except catches a too general exception, possibly buryingunrelated errors.

rule.name: Except doesn't do anything
rule.description: Used when an except clause does nothing but "pass" and there is no "else"clause.

rule.name: Exception doesn't inherit from standard "Exception" class
rule.description: Used when a custom exception class is raised but doesn't inherit from thebuiltin "Exception" class.

rule.name: Exception to catch is the result of a binary "%s" operation
rule.description: Used when the exception to catch is of the form "except A or B:". If intendingto catch multiple, rewrite as "except (A, B):"

rule.name: Use of "property" on an old style class
rule.description: Used when PyLint detect the use of the builtin "property" on an old styleclass while this is relying on new style classes features

rule.name: Assigning to function call which only returns None
rule.description: Used when an assignment is done on a function call but the inferred functionreturns nothing but None.

rule.name: Specify string format arguments as logging function parameters
rule.description: Used when a logging statement has a call form of "logging.<loggingmethod>(format_string % (format_args...))". Such calls should leave stringinterpolation to the logging method itself and be written "logging.<loggingmethod>(format_string, format_args...)" so that the program may avoidincurring the cost of the interpolation in those cases in which no messagewill be logged. For more, see http://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0282/.

rule.name: Format string dictionary key should be a string, not %s
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with adictionary whose keys are not all strings.

rule.name: Unused key %r in format string dictionary
rule.description: Used when a format string that uses named conversion specifiers is used with adictionary that conWtains keys not required by the format string.

rule.name: Anomalous backslash in string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r prefix.
rule.description: Used when a backslash is in a literal string but not as an escape.

rule.name: Anomalous Unicode escape in byte string: '%s'. String constant might be missing an r or u prefix.
rule.description: Used when an escape like \u is encountered in a byte string where it has noeffect.

rule.name: "%s" is not a valid mode for open.
rule.description: Python supports: r, w, a modes with b, +, and U options. Seehttp://docs.python.org/2/library/functions.html#open
